task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for Ali Khaledi Nasab professional profile and current employment
task_1.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently serving as a Senior Manager and Applied Scientist in AI at Amazon's Worldwide Sustainability (WWS) organization in Seattle, Washington. In this role, he drives technical strategy and innovation for Amazon's long-term sustainability and climate commitments through AI and machine learning. ([amazon.science](https://www.amazon.science/author/ali-khaledi?utm_source=openai))

Originally from Iran, Dr. Khaledi moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. in Physics at Ohio University. His doctoral research focused on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with myelinated dendrites. Following his Ph.D., he worked as a postdoctoral researcher at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, where he developed stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

In 2021, Dr. Khaledi joined CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. However, due to unfavorable economic conditions in 2022, CODA was unable to secure additional funding and ceased operations. Subsequently, he transitioned to Amazon in October 2022 as a research scientist in the AWS Network Capacity Planning organization. In 2024, he moved to Amazon's Worldwide Sustainability team to work on generative AI products. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Dr. Khaledi has been committed to continuous learning and professional development. He dedicates time daily to reading and taking courses, aligning with Amazon's core leadership principle of "Learn and Be Curious." ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi has also contributed to the scientific community through publications and presentations. In 2019, he received an American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award to attend the annual APS meeting in Boston, where he presented his research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he has shared his insights on career development through articles on Medium, such as "An Introduction to a Successful Job Interview," reflecting his dedication to mentoring and guiding others in the scientific community. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi's diverse experiences in physics, neuroscience, and AI, combined with his commitment to sustainability, position him as a leader in applying scientific innovation to address global challenges.

task_2.query_used: Search Google for news articles and press releases mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and researcher known for his work in the field of excitable networks and their applications in neuroscience. He has been involved in various academic and professional activities, including presenting his research at conferences and engaging in discussions on international student experiences.

**Academic Contributions:**

- **Research Presentations:** In March 2019, Khaledi Nasab received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the annual APS meeting in Boston. During this conference, he presented his paper titled "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons." His research focused on understanding the dynamical principles of functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

- **Colloquium Talk:** In October 2017, he was invited to give a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster's Department of Physics. His presentation, titled "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements," delved into the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to certain sensory neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

**Publications and Online Presence:**

- Khaledi Nasab has authored several research papers, including "Information processing in tree networks of excitable elements," published in *Physical Review E* in 2021. This work examines the collective response of small random tree networks of diffusively coupled excitable elements. ([stanford.academia.edu](https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab?swp=tc-au-6993172&utm_source=openai))

- He maintains a Medium blog where he shares insights on various topics, such as job interview strategies and book recommendations. For instance, in May 2023, he published an article titled "An Introduction to a Successful Job Interview," offering advice on navigating the interview process. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai))

**Advocacy and Personal Experiences:**

- In April 2017, Khaledi Nasab authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in *Science* magazine. In this piece, he shared his experiences as an international student in the U.S., discussing the challenges posed by the travel ban and the climate of fear among international students. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

These activities highlight Khaledi Nasab's active engagement in both his scientific research and broader discussions on the experiences of international students in the United States.

task_3.query_used: Search academic databases and Google Scholar for publications by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher with a diverse academic background, contributing to fields such as computational neuroscience, nonlinear dynamics, and nanotechnology. He has been affiliated with institutions like Ohio University and Stanford Medicine.

In computational neuroscience, Khaledi-Nasab has co-authored several studies on neuronal network dynamics. Notably, in 2022, he collaborated with J.A. Kromer and P.A. Tass on a paper titled "Long-lasting desynchronization of plastic neuronal networks by double-random coordinated reset stimulation," published in *Frontiers in Network Physiology*. This research explores the effects of coordinated reset stimulation on neuronal network desynchronization. ([med.stanford.edu](https://med.stanford.edu/tass-lab/publications.html?utm_source=openai))

In nanotechnology, Khaledi-Nasab has contributed to research on the synthesis and properties of nanostructured materials. For instance, he co-authored a 2016 study titled "Potato extract as reducing agent and stabiliser in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles," published in the *Journal of Experimental Nanoscience*. This work investigates an eco-friendly method for synthesizing zinc oxide nanoparticles using potato extract. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Khaledi-Nasab has been involved in research on the dynamics of excitable networks. In 2017, he co-authored "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements," published in *Scientific Reports*. This study examines the collective behavior of excitable elements in tree networks. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

His academic contributions are further highlighted by his profile on Google Scholar, where he has an h-index of 10, indicating a significant impact in his research areas. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Overall, Khaledi-Nasab's work spans multiple disciplines, reflecting his interdisciplinary approach to scientific research.

task_5.query_used: Search court records and legal databases for litigation involving Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_5.data:
I searched for litigation involving an individual named Ali Khaledi Nasab but did not find any relevant court records or legal cases associated with that name. It's possible that the name is misspelled, or the individual is not involved in any publicly documented legal proceedings.

However, I did find a case involving a similar name: "KHALEDI v. GLOBAL TRADING LTD HAR (2003)." In this case, Heydar "Shaun" Khaledi, Abdol Rasoul "Ross" Khaledi, and Abbas "Shahram" Khaledi, all brothers, were involved in a business dispute concerning the sale of their interests in several companies. The Texas Court of Appeals addressed issues related to a temporary injunction order against Shaun Khaledi. ([caselaw.findlaw.com](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/court/tx-court-of-appeals/1109873.html?utm_source=openai))

If you can provide more specific information or clarify the name, I would be happy to assist you further.

citations.title: KHALEDI v. GLOBAL TRADING LTD HAR (2003) | FindLaw

task_6.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and doctoral candidate in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University. His research focuses on the dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with tree-like structures. In 2019, he received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the APS annual meeting in Boston, where he presented his work on the dynamics of excitable tree networks and their application to sensory neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

In 2017, Khaledi Nasab delivered a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster's Department of Physics, discussing "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements." His dissertation adviser is Dr. Alexander Neiman, a Professor of Physics at Ohio University. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

Regarding property records and real estate holdings, there is no publicly available information indicating that Ali Khaledi Nasab owns any real estate assets. Public records searches for property ownership under his name did not yield any results. It's important to note that property ownership details are often private and may not be accessible without explicit consent or legal authorization.

task_7.query_used: Search social media platforms (Twitter, Facebook, Instagram) for Ali Khaledi Nasab profiles
task_7.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. After completing his doctorate, he joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery for a research position. He later worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. In 2022, he transitioned to Amazon, where he has been involved in generative AI projects since 2023. His expertise spans nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. He is passionate about leveraging his knowledge to shape the future, serve customers, create new products, and deepen our understanding of complex systems. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In 2024, Ali Khaledi-Nasab joined Amazon Rufus to work on their latest generative AI product. He also gave a colloquium talk at the Department of Physics at Ohio University and was appointed as an adjunct professor of Physics there. Additionally, he served as the editor for the Brain Development section of the three-volume "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," a project he worked on during his time at Stanford University. This collaborative work received the 2024 PROSE Award for "significant contributions" in Clinical Medicine by the Association of American Publishers. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In March 2023, his paper titled "Dynamics of phase oscillator networks with synaptic weight and structural plasticity" was recognized among the top 100 papers in neuroscience. In the same month, he published a piece in Science Magazine titled "Priced out of Science," reflecting on the financial challenges faced by international students pursuing graduate education. In October 2022, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. His recent publications include a paper in Scientific Reports titled "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge" and a paper in Frontiers in Network Physiology titled "Long-lasting desynchronization of plastic neuronal networks by double-random coordinated reset stimulation." ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

For more information about his work and publications, you can visit his personal website at [alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/).

task_8.query_used: Search professional licensing boards and regulatory databases for Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_8.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon's Rufus division. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. He completed his doctoral studies in Physics & Astronomy at Ohio University, focusing on the dynamics of excitable tree networks in sensory neurons. His research has been recognized with awards such as the American Physical Society's Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

After earning his Ph.D., Khaledi Nasab joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery as a researcher, where he worked on developing stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. He later joined CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on treatments for epilepsy, before transitioning to his current role at Amazon. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In addition to his professional work, Khaledi Nasab has been active in addressing challenges faced by international students in the U.S. In 2017, he authored an article in *Science* magazine titled "Standing up to fear," discussing the impact of the U.S. travel ban on international scholars. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

Regarding professional licensing, there is no publicly available information indicating that Khaledi Nasab holds specific professional licenses. His career has been primarily academic and research-focused, with roles in academia and industry that do not typically require such licenses.

task_10.query_used: Search sanctions lists and watchlists for any mentions of Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_10.data: As of June 11, 2025, there are no publicly available records indicating that an individual named Ali Khaledi Nasab is listed on U.S. sanctions lists or watchlists. The U.S. Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) maintains the Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons List (SDN List), which includes individuals and entities subject to U.S. sanctions. A search of the SDN List does not show any entries for Ali Khaledi Nasab. For the most current information, you can consult the official SDN List search tool provided by OFAC. report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 11, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed as a Senior Manager and Applied Scientist at Amazon's Worldwide Sustainability organization. He holds a Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University and has a background in computational neuroscience and nonlinear dynamics.  No red flags were identified in this OSINT investigation.

### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**

- Senior Manager and Applied Scientist at Amazon's Worldwide Sustainability organization (Seattle, WA).
- Focused on AI and machine learning applications for sustainability and climate commitments.
- Previously conducted postdoctoral research at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery.
- Worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup.
- Involved in generative AI projects at Amazon since 2023.

**Business & Financial Activity**

- No significant business or financial affiliations were identified beyond his employment history.

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**

- No legal or criminal records found associated with his name. A case with a similar surname (Khaledi) was identified but involved unrelated individuals in a business dispute.

**Academic / Public Recognition**

- Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University.
- Received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award.
- Presented research at the APS annual meeting in Boston.
- Gave a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster.
- Authored an article titled "Standing up to fear" in *Science* magazine about his experiences as an international student.
- Co-authored publications in computational neuroscience, including research on neuronal network dynamics and depolarization of echo chambers.

**Online / Social Presence**

- Maintains a personal website ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai)).
- Profile listed on Amazon Science ([amazon.science/author/ali-khaledi](https://www.amazon.science/author/ali-khaledi?utm_source=openai)).
- Presence on Academia.edu.


**Other Notable Mentions**

- Originally from Iran, moved to the U.S. in 2014.


### Risk Profile

Based on the available OSINT information, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a **low reputational risk**.  His background demonstrates a strong academic and professional track record with no indications of legal issues or controversies.

judgement.revised_report:
## OSINT Intelligence Report: Ali Khaledi Nasab

**Report Date:** June 11, 2025

### Executive Summary

Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently employed as a Senior Manager and Applied Scientist at Amazon's Worldwide Sustainability organization¹. He holds a Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University and has a background in computational neuroscience and nonlinear dynamics. No red flags were identified in this OSINT investigation.

### Thematic Summary of Key Findings

**Professional / Career Background**

- Senior Manager and Applied Scientist at Amazon's Worldwide Sustainability organization (Seattle, WA)¹
- Focused on AI and machine learning applications for sustainability and climate commitments¹
- Previously conducted postdoctoral research at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery²
- Worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on epilepsy treatments (2021-2022)³
- Joined Amazon in October 2022 as a research scientist in AWS Network Capacity Planning³
- Moved to Amazon's Worldwide Sustainability team in 2024 to work on generative AI products³
- Appointed as adjunct professor of Physics at Ohio University (2024)⁷

**Business & Financial Activity**

- No significant business or financial affiliations were identified beyond his employment history
- No directorial or officer positions in companies found in public registries⁴

**Legal or Criminal Mentions**

- No legal or criminal records found associated with his name⁵
- A case with a similar surname (Khaledi) was identified but involved unrelated individuals in a business dispute (KHALEDI v. GLOBAL TRADING LTD HAR, 2003)⁵

**Academic / Public Recognition**

- Ph.D. in Physics from Ohio University (completed after 2014)²
- Received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award⁶
- Presented research at the APS annual meeting in Boston (2019)⁶
- Gave a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster (October 2017)⁶
- Authored an article titled "Standing up to fear" in *Science* magazine (April 2017) about his experiences as an international student⁶
- Published "Priced out of Science" in *Science* magazine (March 2023) on financial challenges faced by international students⁷
- Co-authored multiple publications in computational neuroscience, including:
  - "Long-lasting desynchronization of plastic neuronal networks by double-random coordinated reset stimulation" (2022)⁸
  - "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge" in *Scientific Reports*⁹
  - "Information processing in tree networks of excitable elements" in *Physical Review E* (2021)⁶
- Has an h-index of 10 according to Google Scholar⁸
- Served as editor for the Brain Development section of the "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," which received the 2024 PROSE Award for Clinical Medicine⁷

**Online / Social Presence**

- Maintains a personal website ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))³
- Profile listed on Amazon Science ([amazon.science/author/ali-khaledi](https://www.amazon.science/author/ali-khaledi?utm_source=openai))¹
- Presence on Academia.edu⁶
- Google Scholar profile with published research⁸
- Medium blog where he shares career advice and insights⁶

**Other Notable Mentions**

- Originally from Iran, moved to the U.S. in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D.²
- No listings found on sanctions lists or watchlists¹⁰
- No evidence of business activities or commercial enterprises in Iran¹¹
- No patents or trademarks filed⁹

### Risk Profile

Based on the available OSINT information, Ali Khaledi Nasab presents a **low reputational risk**. His background demonstrates a strong academic and professional track record with no indications of legal issues, sanctions violations, or controversies. His public writings and research contributions reflect a commitment to scientific advancement and mentorship within the academic community.

---

1. Amazon Science profile (retrieved June 11, 2025)
2. Personal website - About section (alikhaledi.com)
3. Personal website - Homepage (alikhaledi.com)

task_1.query_used: Search LinkedIn for Ali Khaledi Nasab professional profile and current employment
task_1.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently serving as a Senior Manager and Applied Scientist in AI at Amazon's Worldwide Sustainability (WWS) organization in Seattle, Washington. In this role, he drives technical strategy and innovation for Amazon's long-term sustainability and climate commitments through AI and machine learning. ([amazon.science](https://www.amazon.science/author/ali-khaledi?utm_source=openai))

Originally from Iran, Dr. Khaledi moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. in Physics at Ohio University. His doctoral research focused on the collective dynamics of excitable tree networks, particularly in sensory neurons with myelinated dendrites. Following his Ph.D., he worked as a postdoctoral researcher at Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery, where he developed stimulation methods for treating neurological disorders, including Parkinson's disease. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/about?utm_source=openai))

In 2021, Dr. Khaledi joined CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. However, due to unfavorable economic conditions in 2022, CODA was unable to secure additional funding and ceased operations. Subsequently, he transitioned to Amazon in October 2022 as a research scientist in the AWS Network Capacity Planning organization. In 2024, he moved to Amazon's Worldwide Sustainability team to work on generative AI products. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Throughout his career, Dr. Khaledi has been committed to continuous learning and professional development. He dedicates time daily to reading and taking courses, aligning with Amazon's core leadership principle of "Learn and Be Curious." ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi has also contributed to the scientific community through publications and presentations. In 2019, he received an American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics Student Travel Award to attend the annual APS meeting in Boston, where he presented his research on the dynamics of excitable tree networks. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, he has shared his insights on career development through articles on Medium, such as "An Introduction to a Successful Job Interview," reflecting his dedication to mentoring and guiding others in the scientific community. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai))

Dr. Khaledi's diverse experiences in physics, neuroscience, and AI, combined with his commitment to sustainability, position him as a leader in applying scientific innovation to address global challenges.

task_2.query_used: Search Google for news articles and press releases mentioning Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_2.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and researcher known for his work in the field of excitable networks and their applications in neuroscience. He has been involved in various academic and professional activities, including presenting his research at conferences and engaging in discussions on international student experiences.

**Academic Contributions:**

- **Research Presentations:** In March 2019, Khaledi Nasab received the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award, which supported his attendance at the annual APS meeting in Boston. During this conference, he presented his paper titled "Dynamics of excitable tree networks: Application to sensory neurons." His research focused on understanding the dynamical principles of functioning and information processing in sensory neurons with tree-like morphologies. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

- **Colloquium Talk:** In October 2017, he was invited to give a colloquium talk at the College of Wooster's Department of Physics. His presentation, titled "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements," delved into the stochastic dynamics of tree networks of excitable elements, relevant to certain sensory neurons. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2017/10/khaledi-nasab-gives-colloquium-talk-college-wooster/?utm_source=openai))

**Publications and Online Presence:**

- Khaledi Nasab has authored several research papers, including "Information processing in tree networks of excitable elements," published in *Physical Review E* in 2021. This work examines the collective response of small random tree networks of diffusively coupled excitable elements. ([stanford.academia.edu](https://stanford.academia.edu/AliKhalediNasab?swp=tc-au-6993172&utm_source=openai))

- He maintains a Medium blog where he shares insights on various topics, such as job interview strategies and book recommendations. For instance, in May 2023, he published an article titled "An Introduction to a Successful Job Interview," offering advice on navigating the interview process. ([ali-khaledi1989.medium.com](https://ali-khaledi1989.medium.com/an-introduction-to-a-successful-job-interview-b4925c49d98?utm_source=openai))

**Advocacy and Personal Experiences:**

- In April 2017, Khaledi Nasab authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in *Science* magazine. In this piece, he shared his experiences as an international student in the U.S., discussing the challenges posed by the travel ban and the climate of fear among international students. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

These activities highlight Khaledi Nasab's active engagement in both his scientific research and broader discussions on the experiences of international students in the United States.

task_3.query_used: Search academic databases and Google Scholar for publications by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_3.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a researcher with a diverse academic background, contributing to fields such as computational neuroscience, nonlinear dynamics, and nanotechnology. He has been affiliated with institutions like Ohio University and Stanford Medicine.

In computational neuroscience, Khaledi-Nasab has co-authored several studies on neuronal network dynamics. Notably, in 2022, he collaborated with J.A. Kromer and P.A. Tass on a paper titled "Long-lasting desynchronization of plastic neuronal networks by double-random coordinated reset stimulation," published in *Frontiers in Network Physiology*. This research explores the effects of coordinated reset stimulation on neuronal network desynchronization. ([med.stanford.edu](https://med.stanford.edu/tass-lab/publications.html?utm_source=openai))

In nanotechnology, Khaledi-Nasab has contributed to research on the synthesis and properties of nanostructured materials. For instance, he co-authored a 2016 study titled "Potato extract as reducing agent and stabiliser in a facile green one-step synthesis of ZnO nanoparticles," published in the *Journal of Experimental Nanoscience*. This work investigates an eco-friendly method for synthesizing zinc oxide nanoparticles using potato extract. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Khaledi-Nasab has been involved in research on the dynamics of excitable networks. In 2017, he co-authored "Emergent stochastic oscillations and signal detection in tree networks of excitable elements," published in *Scientific Reports*. This study examines the collective behavior of excitable elements in tree networks. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

His academic contributions are further highlighted by his profile on Google Scholar, where he has an h-index of 10, indicating a significant impact in his research areas. ([scholar.google.com](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Ash32BAAAAAJ&utm_source=openai))

Overall, Khaledi-Nasab's work spans multiple disciplines, reflecting his interdisciplinary approach to scientific research.

task_5.query_used: Search court records and legal databases for litigation involving Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_5.data:
I searched for litigation involving an individual named Ali Khaledi Nasab but did not find any relevant court records or legal cases associated with that name. It's possible that the name is misspelled, or the individual is not involved in any publicly documented legal proceedings.

However, I did find a case involving a similar name: "KHALEDI v. GLOBAL TRADING LTD HAR (2003)." In this case, Heydar "Shaun" Khaledi, Abdol Rasoul "Ross" Khaledi, and Abbas "Shahram" Khaledi, all brothers, were involved in a business dispute concerning the sale of their interests in several companies. The Texas Court of Appeals addressed issues related to a temporary injunction order against Shaun Khaledi. ([caselaw.findlaw.com](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/court/tx-court-of-appeals/1109873.html?utm_source=openai))

If you can provide more specific information or clarify the name, I would be happy to assist you further.

citations.title: KHALEDI v. GLOBAL TRADING LTD HAR (2003) | FindLaw

task_7.query_used: Search social media platforms (Twitter, Facebook, Instagram) for Ali Khaledi Nasab profiles
task_7.data:
Ali Khaledi-Nasab is a physicist and AI scientist currently working at Amazon Rufus. Originally from Iran, he moved to the United States in 2014 to pursue his Ph.D. After completing his doctorate, he joined Stanford University's Department of Neurosurgery for a research position. He later worked at CODA Biotherapeutics, a gene therapy startup focused on developing treatments for epilepsy. In 2022, he transitioned to Amazon, where he has been involved in generative AI projects since 2023. His expertise spans nonlinear dynamics, stochastic processes, signal processing, statistics, biophysics, and network sciences. He is passionate about leveraging his knowledge to shape the future, serve customers, create new products, and deepen our understanding of complex systems. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In 2024, Ali Khaledi-Nasab joined Amazon Rufus to work on their latest generative AI product. He also gave a colloquium talk at the Department of Physics at Ohio University and was appointed as an adjunct professor of Physics there. Additionally, he served as the editor for the Brain Development section of the three-volume "Encyclopedia of Child and Adolescent Health," a project he worked on during his time at Stanford University. This collaborative work received the 2024 PROSE Award for "significant contributions" in Clinical Medicine by the Association of American Publishers. ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

In March 2023, his paper titled "Dynamics of phase oscillator networks with synaptic weight and structural plasticity" was recognized among the top 100 papers in neuroscience. In the same month, he published a piece in Science Magazine titled "Priced out of Science," reflecting on the financial challenges faced by international students pursuing graduate education. In October 2022, he joined Amazon as a research scientist in the AWS network capacity team. His recent publications include a paper in Scientific Reports titled "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge" and a paper in Frontiers in Network Physiology titled "Long-lasting desynchronization of plastic neuronal networks by double-random coordinated reset stimulation." ([alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/?utm_source=openai))

For more information about his work and publications, you can visit his personal website at [alikhaledi.com](https://www.alikhaledi.com/).

task_9.query_used: Search trademark and patent databases for intellectual property filed by Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_9.data:
After reviewing available patent and trademark databases, there is no evidence of intellectual property filed by or about Ali Khaledi Nasab. His professional work primarily focuses on physics and computational neuroscience, with notable publications in these fields. For instance, he co-authored a paper titled "Depolarization of echo chambers by random dynamical nudge," which explores mechanisms to reduce polarization in social networks. ([export.arxiv.org](https://export.arxiv.org/abs/2101.04079?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, Ali Khaledi Nasab has been recognized for his academic contributions, such as receiving the American Physical Society (APS) Division of Biological Physics 2019 Student Travel Award to attend the annual APS meeting in Boston. ([ohio-forum.com](https://www.ohio-forum.com/2019/05/khaledi-nasab-receives-aps-travel-award-to-attend-conference/?utm_source=openai))

While he has made significant contributions to his field, there is no public record of him filing patents or trademarks related to his work.

task_10.query_used: Search sanctions lists and watchlists for any mentions of Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_10.data: As of June 11, 2025, there are no publicly available records indicating that an individual named Ali Khaledi Nasab is listed on U.S. sanctions lists or watchlists. The U.S. Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) maintains the Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons List (SDN List), which includes individuals and entities subject to U.S. sanctions. A search of the SDN List does not show any entries for Ali Khaledi Nasab. For the most current information, you can consult the official SDN List search tool provided by OFAC. ([ofac.treasury.gov](https://ofac.treasury.gov/recent-actions/20240423?utm_source=openai))

citations.title: Counter Terrorism Designations; Hostages and Wrongfully Detained U.S. Nationals Designations | Office of Foreign Assets Control

task_11.query_used: Search Iranian business registries and commercial databases for Ali Khaledi Nasab
task_11.data:
Ali Khaledi Nasab is a physicist and astronomer who pursued his doctoral studies at Ohio University in Athens, Ohio. In April 2017, he authored an article titled "Standing up to fear," published in *Science* magazine, where he shared his experiences as an international student in the United States during the early years of the Trump administration. In this piece, he discussed the challenges faced by international students amid political changes and the importance of institutional support. ([academia.edu](https://www.academia.edu/32689067/Standing_up_to_fear?utm_source=openai))

Regarding Iranian business registries and commercial databases, there is no publicly available information linking Ali Khaledi Nasab to any business activities or commercial enterprises in Iran. His professional profile appears to be primarily academic, with no evidence of involvement in business ventures within Iran.
